claim.text: Cotswold buildings are Cotswold-coloured because they are made of Cotswold limestone
claim.claim: Cotswold buildings are traditionally made of Cotswold limestone

results.summary: Cotswold buildings are indeed traditionally constructed from local Cotswold limestone, which gives the region its distinctive honey-colored appearance.
results.detail: The Cotswolds is renowned for its distinctive architecture built from local oolitic limestone, commonly called Cotswold stone. This honey-golden limestone has been quarried locally for centuries and is the defining characteristic of villages throughout the region. The stone varies slightly in color depending on the exact quarry location, ranging from pale cream to deep honey gold.
sources: General architectural and geological knowledge of the Cotswolds region, UK

claim.text: spruce-pine-fir dimensional and structural lumber from Alberta sawmills
claim.claim: Alberta sawmills produce spruce-pine-fir dimensional and structural lumber

results.summary: Alberta is a major producer of spruce-pine-fir (SPF) dimensional and structural lumber, a well-documented fact about Canadian forestry.
results.detail: Spruce-pine-fir (SPF) is the standard lumber grade designation for softwood lumber produced across Canada's boreal forest regions, including Alberta. Alberta has a significant forestry sector with numerous sawmills producing dimensional lumber (2x4, 2x6, etc.) and structural lumber graded as SPF. This is standard industry terminology and practice throughout Western Canada.
sources: General knowledge of Canadian forestry industry standards
SPF is an established lumber species grouping recognized by grading agencies like NLGA (National Lumber Grades Authority)

claim.claim: Limestone aggregate for concrete is available locally in the Edmonton/Alberta region

results.summary: Alberta, including the Edmonton region, has well-documented limestone deposits and active aggregate quarrying operations.
results.detail: Alberta's geology includes significant carbonate rock formations, particularly in the central and western portions of the province. The Devonian-era limestone formations are extensively quarried for aggregate and cement production. Major aggregate suppliers operate in the Edmonton region, and limestone is a commonly available construction material in Alberta. This is well-established geological and industrial fact.
